testing-library.1: Testing Library emphasizes testing the application from the user's perspective. It encourages tests that resemble how users interact with the UI.
testing-library.2: Testing Library promotes accessibility by default. Its query methods encourage tests that ensure the application is usable by everyone.
testing-library.3: It was initially created for React and later adapted for other frameworks like Vue.

react.1: React was initially developed by Jordan Walke, a software engineer at Facebook, and was first used in Facebook's newsfeed in 2011. It was later open-sourced in 2013.
react.2: React uses a virtual DOM, which is a lightweight copy of the actual DOM
react.3: React's key prop can actually be any unique value, including non-primitive values like objects or arrays.

vue.1: Vue.js was created by Evan You, a former Google employee, who wanted to create a more lightweight and flexible framework compared to Angular.
vue.2: Vue is designed to be incrementally adoptable. This means you can integrate it into existing projects gradually.
vue.3: Vue has a particularly strong and active community in Asia, especially in China.

html.1: HTML was invented by Tim Berners-Lee, the same person who invented the World Wide Web, in 1990.
html.2: HTML is constantly evolving with new standards and features. HTML5, the latest major version, introduced features like <video>, <audio>, and <canvas>
html.3: The <title> tag is not actually required to be inside the <head> elementâ€”even though it is traditionally placed there.

javascript.1: JavaScript was created by Brendan Eich at Netscape in just 10 days in May 1995. It was initially named Mocha, then LiveScript, before finally becoming JavaScript.
javascript.2: JavaScript is standardized by ECMAScript, which ensures compatibility across different browsers and JavaScript engines.
javascript.3: NaN (Not a Number) is technically a number and not something 'not-a-number' console.log(typeof NaN);  // 'number'

dev-to.1: Dev.to is known for its welcoming and inclusive community, where developers of all skill levels can share their knowledge and experiences.
dev-to.2: The Dev.to platform is open-source, which means anyone can contribute to its development and suggest improvements.
dev-to.3: The Dev.to platform is built using Ruby on Rails, a web application framework known for its convention over configuration philosophy.
